user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_update:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_update (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
               const void *data,
               size_t length)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
    MHD_MD5_update (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, (const uint8_t *) data, length);
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
    MHD_SHA256_update (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, (const uint8_t *) data, length);
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
    MHD_SHA512_256_update (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx,
                           (const uint8_t *) data, length);
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (0);   /* May not happen */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  da->hashing = true;
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of the Standard Library function memcmp (or other string-comparison functions such as strcmp/strncmp) in the provided digest_update function. The code only calls internal update routines (MHD_MD5_update, MHD_SHA256_update, MHD_SHA512_256_update) with a data pointer and an explicit length, which indicates binary-buffer processing rather than comparisons of null-terminated strings. There are no expressions comparing char buffers or pointers that would suggest a memcmp-based string comparison. Therefore there are no fragments in this function that need to be investigated for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14. If you want a deeper check, provide the implementations of the called update functions and any macros to verify they themselves do not call memcmp on null-terminated strings.
